title: Wage garnishment.
question: I took out an unsecured loan for $2500.00 about 3 years ago, due to financial hardship I couldn't fulfill my financial obligation, yesterday, a sheriff stopped by my work site and gave me papers that my wages are going to be garnished, I'm assuming that my HR department has a copy as well, if they garnish 25% of each pay check, I would hardly be able to live, is there anything I can do to stop or maybe reduce/modify the amount of garnishment? by the way, the total amount owed is now $3700.00 total, thats with interest and penalties, please help, thank you.
question_tags: Small business loans,Bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Wage garnishment,Nondischargeable debt and student loans,Bankruptcy and debt,Lawsuits and disputes,Sued for debt,Default judgment
answers:
Yes, you can file a Claim of Exemption along with a Financial Statement. A Claim of Exemption is a form a debtor files with the levying officer (like the LA County Sheriff) explaining why the wages that the creditor wants the debtor’s employer to garnish should be exempt (excluded).

The forms are:

http://www.courts.ca.gov/documents/wg006.pdf

http://www.courts.ca.gov/documents/wg007.pdf

Turn in 2 copies of the Claim of Exemption (Form WG-006) and the Financial Statement (Form WG-007) to the levying officer in your case (like the sheriff) within 10 days of receiving the Notice of Levy. Keep one copy of both forms for yourself.

Your employer will hold on to the money garnished until 10 days go by and the creditor hasn’t opposed the claim of exemption, or the judge makes a decision at the hearing on the claim of exemption. If the creditor doesn’t oppose your claim of exemption, your employer will return the wages to you. If the creditor opposes your claim of exemption, you will receive a Notice of Opposition to Claim of Exemption and Notice of Hearing on Claim of Exemption that will set a court date for a judge to make a decision. If the judge agrees with your claim of exemption, you will get the money back. If the judge agrees with the creditor, your employer will send the money to the creditor every month.

The papers the you received should have a case number. You need to go to the courthouse of the court where the judgment was entered. Review the court's file in your case. Get copies of the relevant documents. Then consult an attorney about making a motion to set aside the default judgment. You should also file a Claim of Exemption, seeking to reduce the wage garnishment.

I have linked below my blog that answers your questions on what options you have. Of course, bankruptcy to discharge this debt is an option, but I am concerned that you the lawsuit was not properly served on you before a judgment was entered. The type of debt also matters, such as student loan, credit card, business loan.

I have had success for clients setting aside improperly served default judgments, which then allows the court to consider the merits of the case and the debt. It also opens up settlement possibilities. Below is more info on reducing the garnishment amount to be affordable for you.

I have on Avvo a legal guide, see link below, on preparing the Claim of Exemption and reducing the amount so that the amount garnished from a debtor's wages is fair or even fully exempt. For many people, 25% is unbearable and can be lowered, if the situation is properly presented by Claim of Exemption. Good luck with this and please be sure to act promptly, so that you get relief soon.
